FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF 404 NEBRASKA STATE PENITENTIARY To His Excellency, Honorable John H. Morehead, Governor, and to the Honorable members of the Board of Com - missioners of State Institutions, Silas A. Holcomb, Howard Kennedy and Henry Gerden. Gentlemen : I have the honor, herewith, to submit to you my report as Warden of the Nebraska State Penitentiary, for the biennial period beginning December 1st, 1912, and ending November 30th, 1914, during which period Honorable S. M. Melick was Warden from December 1st, 1912, to January 17th, 1913. I wish to present to you, gentlemen, a complete report of my work since I took charge of the institution showing conditions as I found them and conditions of the institu - tion at the present time. On taking charge I found the buildings and the general surroundings in a dilapidated condition. The roofs of both cell houses were in very bad condition, letting the rain and melting snow run down through the iron cell houses which cost the State a large sum of money. The iron in the cell houses had become rusted and would in a short time be of little value. We found it necessary to replace the roofs on the west cell house and an asbestos roof was put on and on the east cell house a gravel and tar roof was put on. The administration building was found to have a leaky and bad roof and had to be repaired in many places. I found the cells in bad condition and it was necessary to paint all of them. I also found that the bath house was in a very un - sanitary condition. There were twenty or more old, rusty bath tubs, where disease could be transmitted from one in - mate to another. We at once installed shower baths and now have a clean and sanitary bath house. The old dining room and kitchen were unfit for use and, after completing our beautiful dining room, I can truthfully :ay that we have one of the finest prison dining rooms in the

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 405 vest, equipped with new furniture and china dishes taking the place of the old tin plates and tin cups. We have a fine sanitary and well equipped kitchen, with fine range and steam cookers. Until we took charge, two years ago, the prison kitchen did not have a range or stove of any kind. The hospital facilities were very poor until the comple - tion of our new building but we now have a very modern and sanitary hospital for the care of the sick. Our sewerage system was badly in need of repair and drainage was poor. This we have improved in many ways. Much of the plumbing was rusted out and pipes were leak - ing all over the institution, most of which had to be torn out and replaced by new pipes. Our steam pipes were laid in the ground, but this has been improved by taking up the pipes and replacing them in conduit, thus saving much fuel. The bath house and laundry roofs were found in bad shape and it was found necessary to replace them with new roofs. The water supply was inadequate for the institution, and during the summer of 1913 we were compelled to haul water from College View, two miles distant, in tanks for washing and flushing purposes. For many years this shortage of water has existed and much money had been spent in former years trying to get a sufficient supply of water close to the institution. We decided that it was un - wise to try further for water close to the institution and after putting down a test well about a half mile north of the institution and gettin? an abundant supply of good, pure water, we decided to locate our wells and pumping station there. We now have an abundance of water for all pur - poses, which is forced through the mains from the wells to the reservoir south of the prison. The pump at the well is run by a dynamo, power being furnished from the plant at the institution. The outside of the prison was in total darkness at night. We had cement lamp posts made by the inmates and erected in front of the administration building and also in front of both cell houses. The grounds are now well lighted.

406 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF The guard's dining room was also badly in need of re - pairs. A re-inforced concrete floor was put in over their dining hall and over this four rooms were built for the steward's living quarters. We have converted our old dining room into a good school-room. We have sixty school desks which we pur - chased second hand. The room is now well equipped to carry on our school work. Mr. O'Connell, who is an exper - ienced school man, looks after the school, assisted by sev - eral of the inmates as teachers. Our enrollment last win - ter was one hundred forty-five and the results were very satisfactory. When the school opened we had thirty-five of our boys who could neither read nor write. At the close of the term last summer all except one could both read and write. The grounds in front of the building were very low and the water, in time of heavy rains, did not carry off. We have improved this condition by hauling in about seven hundred loads of earth, which raised the grounds about two feet in front of the prison. Our old kitchen has ben cleaned and painted and equipped for a sanitary vegetable room, where vegetables are peeled and prepared for the different kitchens. We found over one thousand window lights broken in the different buildings. These have all been replaced. The cement walks in the prison yard were gone to pieces and have been replaced by new walks. We have been handicapped, heretofore, on account of not having any winter feed for our stock. This has been taken care of by the erection of a new cement silo, which holds about one hundred seventy-five tons of ensilage. We will now endeavor to build up a good dairy herd. All of our buildings have been thoroughly renovated and painted. Gentlemen, I think the above items cover the improvements for the past two years. REGARDING DOPE TRAFFIC IN THE INSTITUTION On taking charge we found that about seventy-five to one hundred men were addicted to the use of morphine and

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 407 other opiates. We were compelled to lock up these unfor - tunate men and place a guard over them in order to prevent them from harming themselves. After several weeks of treatment by our prison physician, Dr. Williams, assisted by Dr. Humphrey, we were able to cure these men of this awful habit and we now have them back to their normal condition and they fully appreciate the fact that they have given up the habit. We discovered that this traffic had been carried on by some unscrupulous and unworthy em - ployees of the State and some working under the contrac - tors. Some of these men had ordered morphine in bottles by the gross from Chicago and other cities and made large profits by the sale of it to the unfortunates who had fallen victims of their traffic. I at once discharged all of the em - ployees who were in any way connected with the traffic. I can now truthfully say that we have not one dope fiend in the institution and the men are now enjoying good health and the moral atmosphere of the institution is the very best. DISCIPLINE The discipline of the institution is neither unduly mild nor severe. Continued stresss is laid upon the importance of self-government on the part of the inmates. The of - ficers are urged to stimulate in them the desire to rule from within. PAROLES We are highly gratified to report that the parole sys - tem in operation is becoming more satisfactory from year to year. The per cent of reclamations has been much great - er the last two years than at any previous period, only fifteen per cent having violated the conditions of their pa - roles in the past year. Two years ago parole violations were as high as forty-two per cent. The reason for this, I think, wes largely due to the dope traffic which was carried on in this institution. When men went out using the drug in nearly every instance he was returned.

FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF 408 EMPLOYMENT FOR INMATES The last session of our legislature abolished the con - tract system in our penal institutions. The broom contrac - tors who have employed from one hundred fifty to two hun - dred of our boys are slowly moving out and by the time the legislature has convened they will be working but few men, if any. This is a problem which every State is confronted with where the contract system has been abolished. As to which is the best and most profitable work for the State to engage in, is a very important question which must be passed upon and decided by the next legislature. When the legislature passed this law it also passed a law prohibiting the State from manufacturing any article which would come in competition with any industry now operating in Ne - braska. They also appropriated thirty-five thousand dollars for the establishment of a twine plant to be operated by the State. On investigation we find that it would be impossible to build and equip a twine plant for less than a hundred and fifty thousand dollars. In addition to this amount it would be necessary to have not less than one hundred twenty-five thousand dollars as a revolving fund to purchase raw mater - ial and carry on the business of manufacturing twine. We also find that the cost of coal at the price we must pay would cost a great amount of money and the profits in the twine business being very small we do not believe it the proper industry for the State to engage in. RECOMMENDATIONS I would respectfully recommend to the legislature that they so modify the law so as to allow the Honorable Board of Commissioners of State Institutions to establish the broom industry and the furniture business in this institution. The work carried on in a penal institution should be work which requires a great amount of hand work and that the value of the article should be represented mostly in the labor performed on such articles. We could furnish brooms and furniture for the different State institutions which, of course, is a very small item, so small that it makes it neces - sary that we be permitted to put those articles on the open

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 409 market. I am confident that the tax payers of this State do not desire to have these men left idle on our hands and the small amount of manufacturing that we do at the prison in the lines of brooms and /urniture cannot and will not, in the least, harm industries of free labor already established in our State. We feel confident that an appropriation of not more than thirty-five thousand dollars, with the machin - ery we already have, will equip our broom and furniture shops and carry on these two industries. We are confident that it will bring more revenue into the State than the twine business owing to the small amount we would have invested and give many more men employment than would the twine business. ROAD WORK Governor Morehead has for many years advocated working as many of our boys as possible on the roads of the State. In this matter I heartily agree with him and would recommend to the Honorable Legislature that they pass some legislation whereby the State can work a number of these men at building roads. FARMING We have in our prison farm only two hundred ninety - six acres. Under our honor system we work on this land, during the crop and vegetable season, from twenty-five to forty men. If we had another half section close to our in - stitution we could work many more men outside the walls on the farm. Therefore, I recommend that the legislature look into the advisability of purchasing more land for the penitentiary. REFORMATORY In view of the fact that there is some question regard - ing the advisability of establishing a Reformatory, in case the Reformatory is not established, I recommend that the penal laws be changed so that every man between the ages of eighteen and twenty-five years and, having a limited edu - cation and sentenced to the penitentiary, a part of his sen-

410 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OK tence shall be that during his incarceration he shall attend school at least two hours a day. And further I would rec - ommend, providing the Reformatory is not established, that the legislature appropriate a sufficient amount for the erec - tion of a school building at the penitentiary. It has become apparent to a large number of our jurors and legislators, and I firmly believe they are right on this question, that the protection of society and the reformation of the offender are the elements always to be considered. REGARDING ELIG1BLES FOR PAROLE In almost all of the progressive States of the Union they now have their parole laws so arranged that, after a life-man has served a certain number of years and shows a disposition to reform, the Board of Parole can parole him. They also have laws where long term men, such as twenty-five and thirty-year men, after they have served six, seven, or eight years, and show a disposi - tion to reform, the Board of Parole shall have the right to parole them. I would heartily recommend that our legis - lature pass some legislation along this line as it is a difficult matter to reform men when they have nothing to look for - ward to but a life behind the walls. We have men in this institution who have been sentenced for twenty-one and thirty years who are as susceptible to reformation as those who have only a sentence of one year. CANNING FACTORY 1 would recommend to the Honorable Board that a small canning plant be placed in one of the old rooms of the fac - tory building for the purpose of canning corn, beans, peas, tomatoes, and fruits of different kinds. I would recommend that a small plant be put in here with a capacity of canning for our own institution the first year and, if it proved sat - isfactory and economical. I would recommend that tHe ca - pacity be increased later and that we do canning for all the State institutions. The Government now has a plant for steam canning, which I understand is very satisfactory, and the plant could be installed with a small amount of capital.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 411 RtCREAfiON AND AMUSEMENTS Our recreation and amusement consist of yard priv - ileges every Sunday morning for two hours. The men are permitted to associate and converse together during the time they are in the yards. During the summer months the Beatrice Creamery Company kindly donated to us fifty gal - lons of butter milk each Saturday. This was put on ice on Saturday and placed in the yard for the men on Sunday forenoons. We have abolished the old rule of silence at the meals. During the baseball season we played ninety games of baseball, playing the amateur teams of Lincoln and the State Farm. We played those games in the evenings after the boys had finished their tasks. As our enclosure is not large enough to play on the inside, we were obliged to play outside the walls, the boys being taken out in groups of from seventy-five to one hundred twenty-five. We have a band and orchestra. The orchestra furnishes music in the new dining hall during the meal hour. We expect during the coming year to purchase a moving picture machine. This will be purchased from a fund made from the receipts at shows which the boys expect to put on at Thanksgiving Christmas and New Year. We also expect to put on a good show during the session of the legislature. 1 wish to state that the boys have fully appreciated the new privileges they have been granted and not one has taken advantage of them in any way. REGARDING REVENUE FROM SHOPS As the number of men for the past two years has been much less than in former years and the fact that we em - ployed as many as forty men putting in our new water sys - tem and about the same number employed on the new build - ing and other improvements and also an unusually large number have been engaged in raising the garden truck, the amount of money from the shops turned into the State is not so large as in some previous years. Another reason for th'e amount not being so large is that, for the past two months, we have had comparatively few men working in

412 KIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF the broom factory, as the contractors are removing their machinery and slowly moving out. Our chair factory, here - tofore, has been working fifty-two men, but, owing to the European War making it impossible for them to get suffi - cient material for the reed and fiber chairs, the number of men has been cut down to thirty. The material used in making these chairs is purchased almost entirely in Ger - many. ESCAPES We have had no escapes from the institution since tak - ing charge. One man, who had been furloughed for a few days to Tecumseh, broke faith with us, but he was captured and brought back. We worked the boys on the outside with - out guards. Our honor system has worked very satisfac - torily and we expect to work a greater number outside dur - ing the coming season. FOOD FOR INMATES We are feeding our men well. Heretofore there was no variety of food. There was no stove or range to prepare it. We hear no complaint whatever about the food since we have changed the old menu of hash every morning. Fol - lowing is our average daily menu : Breakfast — Fried breakfast bacon, brown gravy, fried po - tatoes, wheat bread, coffee. Dinner — Roast pork, boiled navy beans, stewed turnips, cof - fee. Supper — Cottage fried potatoes, brown gravy, hot biscuits, syrup, tea. RELIGIOUS WORK It is with deep sorrow that I report to the Governor and Honorable Board the death of our venerable and grand old chaplain who passed away last January. For eight years he has looked after the spiritual welfare of our boys and the good work he has done for those who are now here and those who have gone out into the world shall live on as a monu - ment to his memory. I heartily commend the Honorable

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 413 Board for their wisdom in the selection of our new Chaplain, Rev. E. M. Johnson. He is doing a great work among the men and they all hold him in high esteem. Our volunteer, Catholic Chaplain, Reverend Father Moran has for many years looked after the spiritual welfare of the boys of that faith. He makes his visits every two weeks and is doing a good work. With these two gentlemen working in perfect harmony for the spiritual welfare of the unfortunate has placed the moral standard of this institution on a high plane. The good people of Lincoln and the surrounding suburbs who so kindly and unselfishly give their services every Sunday to their Sunday school classes deserve a great deal of credit for their work in the interest of humanity. The superintendent of the Sunday school, Mr. Cordner, has been a faithful worker for many years and deserves much credit for his work among the boys. I desire to thank all of those good people for their hearty co-operation for the betterment of the men in this institution. Dr. Leavitt and Chaplain Johnson and Dr. Bullock and Captain Gifford deserve a great deal of credit for their faithful work in securing employment for the paroled and discharged boys, many of whom they have placed in posi - tions where they are making good and are a credit to so - ciety. CONCLUSION In conclusion I wish to express to Deputy Warden Har - mon my sincere gratitude for his faithful and loyal service to the State and the support he has given me at all times in the elimination of the dope traffic and the reforms that we have brought about during the past two years and I desire to state to the Honorable Board that much credit is due to him for the good and faithful service he has performed. I also desire to express my sincere thanks to Captain of the Guards, Mr. Kavanaugh and all the other guards and em - ployees who have been faithful to every trust and assisted me in cleaning up the dope traffic. And to you, gentlemen, members of the Board of Commissioners of State Institu - tions and Governor Morehead. 1 wish to thank you for the

414 KIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF kind consideration and official courtesy you have always shown me. The statistical report of the institution by the chief clerk, Mr. James O'Connell, the financial report up to the time the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions took charge, also the report of the chaplain, librarian and mat - ron, and the report from the farm you will find filed in this report. Fenton, Warden: It is with pleasure that 1 submit to you a report of the work in my department of your institution. From the death of Chaplain P. C. Johnson in January of this year until my appointment, June 1st. the Prison was without a regular Chaplain ; different persons were secured to con duct the regular Chapel services on Sunday. Since my appointment, the services have been conducted by me per sonally, or under my direct supervision. 1 have been ably assisted by Mr. J. E. Storm and his daughter Esther, wh> had charge of the music until August, and by Mr. J. E. Enix and Mr. Thompson, who have directed the music since Mr. Storm's retirement. Other assistance has been given by Mr. J. G. Cordner, who has superintended the Sunday School, and a competent corps of teachers who have faithfully done their work in that department of the religious activity. Soon after I took up the work I arranged to meet all who wanted to receive special Biblical instruction and a class of 66 members was organized to meet on Saturday night for Bible study. Under the direction of this depart - ment, a Volunteer Prison League was organized- and ■ 107 of the prisoners joined this body by taking the following pledge: _•---". "I promise to pray morning and evening; to read the W. T. Fenton. Warden.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 415 'Day Book' every day; to abstain from all intoxicating drinks; from the use of profanity, and all other indecent language; to obey all the rules and discipline of the in - stitution ; to keep cheerful and enlist others in the 'Prison League'." The League meetings were held on Monday nights until the night school began and, since that time are held in connection with the Bible Study on Saturday nights. Thu members of the League make up the program for thes._> meetings and conduct them under my direction. I spend every Sunday afternoon visiting the prisoner - in their cells and talking to them about their moral and spiritual welfare. At least twice a week I visit the men in the shops in order to give a word of cheer and encourage - ment while they are busy at their tasks. The moral condition of the prison body is on a high plane. The prisoners show a deep appreciation of the re - ligious work that is bein? done. They are very attentive at the Chapel services and at the Saturday night Bible study. The attendance at the Sunday School is voluntary and about half the inmates attend this part of the service. As one of the results, we ljave seen four conversions in the past six months. Besides the work that has been mentioned, Father Moran of the Catholic Church conducts special services for those who are associated with the Catholic faith. These services are held each two weeks on Saturday night and Sunday morning and have been well attended, with profit able results. My work as Chaplain has been very pleasant and i have been most cordially treated by the officers, guards, shop-overseers, and the occupants of the prison. I want to express to you, especially, my appreciation of your as - sistance and co-operation in the religious work in the in - stitution. Respectfully submitted E. M. 416 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF REPORT OF LIBRARIAN To. W. T. Fenton, Warden: It is with pleasure that I submit to you a report of the library for the past biennium from December 1st, 1912, to November 30th, 1914. The Prison Library is under the State Library Com - mission and we receive frequent visits from Miss Florence Waugh who has general supervision of the libraries in the State institutions. There are thirty-two hundred carefully classified vol - umes on the shelves and a complete catalogue is given to each inmate with the privilege of selecting his reading. One of the prisoners acts as librarian under the supervis - ion of the Chaplain. The present assistant has been in this position for nine months and his records show that ten thousand two hundred forty-nine volumes have been read in that time, making an average of eleven hundred thirty-eight volumes per month, or four books for each man. The character of the reading may be seen by one month's itemized report for October, 1914: General Works 16 Philosophy 45 Religious 45 Sociology 24 Science 23 Useful Arts 25 Fine Arts 21 Literature 228 History 74 Travel 58 Biography 60 Fiction 791 Total 1427 It is the purpose to have works read which are of a high character and to keep out such reading matter as would not be uplifting. Respectfully submitted, E. M. Johnson, Librarian. Livolv, Nebmska. Nwmber 90, I91h

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 417 REPORT OF CLERK To. W. T. Fenton, Warden Herewith is submitted the report of the clerk's office for the biennium, 1913-14 : The report of the financial affairs of the institution differs very materially from the preceding biennial reports. The Board of Commissioners of State Institutions, which took charge early in the biennium, adopted a different sys - tem of monthly reports and required that a detailed state - ment of all financial transactions in each of the several in - stitutional funds be transmitted to that office each month, where they will be compiled, and it is the policy of the Board to make all future biennial reports of all the State insti - tutions both to the governor and the legislature from that office. The instructions of the Board for this biennium re - quire that each institution report the condition of each of the funds from the beginning of the biennium, December 1, 1912, to April 1, 1913. Accordingly, I have given a brief statement of the balances on hand December 1, 1912, the total expenditures for the period, and the balances April 1, 1913. With respect to the earnings of the institution the same prevails in the Institution Cash Fund. In the earn - ings from other sources the earnings are given for the biennium. A comparison of the earnings from the broom and fur - niture contracts during this and preceding years show a decrease. This is due to three causes. The number of in - mates has averaged about one-fourth less and during the latter part of the biennium the broom contract, because of the law abolishing contract labor, has been reducing the number of men employed. During the larger part of the biennium it was necessary to employ a large number of in - mates on the new construction work done. An average of thirty men were employed on the new dining room and hos - pital, enlarging and repairing the sewerage and plumbing systems, putting in the new water system and in general

418 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF repairs on the entire plant. This labor saved the State sev - eral thousand dollars. You will notice a difference in the sources of earnings. Formerly it was the custom to report all income as earnings. I have eliminated all sources of income but those that show actual earnint-s. These are Special Labor, Chapel Stand, and Barber Shop. To these should be added the steward's report of earnings on the farm. The income from all other sources, such as dining room, sale of old horses, cows, hides, bones, and all other useless materials should be credited to the funds that produced them. This makes the earnings comparatively less. An inspection of the tables submitted by the Board for the report on the Movement of Population, Statistics, and Vital matters will show that there is much data called for that has not been recorded in this office. This is to be re - gretted, as these statistics are of the utmost importance in the study and care of the State's defectives. I would sug - cest the standardizing of these forms and the procuring of suitable books of record so that all future statistics may be full and reliable. Those given cannot be very satisfactory to the Board. Respectfully yours. Jas. O'Connell, Clerk Lincoln, Nebraska. November 30, 191k.

FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF 442 MATRON'S REPORT To W. T. Fenton, Warden: I herewith submit my report as matron of the Ne - braska State Penitentiary for the biennium beginning De - cember 1, 1912, to November 30, 1914. The female ward was under Mrs. S. M. Melick from December 1, 1912, to January 17, 1913, and under Mrs. W. T. Fenton from January 17, 1913, to September 11, 1913, since which time I have had charge. At the beginning of this biennium there were in the female department seven negroes and one Indian woman, while at the present time we have four white women and one negress. The women's quarters have been thoroughly renovated, having been painted and varnished throughout, and they now present a very neat and clean appearance. Besides taking care of their own clothing and rooms, the women do the laundry work for the warden's, deputy warden's and steward's families. They also occupy them - selves by reading books and magazines from the library and in making their own clothing. The discipline of the female ward has been very good during the biennium The women attend chapel services regularly every Sunday and seem to take great interest in the Sunday school lessons. Mrs. Storm had charge of the women's Sunday school class for some time, but owing to ill health resigned in favor of Mrs. Oldham. Both the ladies have taken great interest in the female inmates and have done everything by counsel and advice to raise the

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 443 moral standard. We wish to thank both Mrs. Storm and Mrs. Oldham for the interest shown. During the past year one woman has been transferred to the Hospital for the Insane of Nebraska, Norfolk. The health of the inmates has been very good and no one has had any serious illness. Respectfully submitted Minnie Murphy, Matron. Lincoln, Nebraska, November 30, 19H. \ REPORT OF CATHOLIC CHAPLAIN To W. T. Fenton, Warden: I take pleasure, as the voluntary Catholic chaplain of the Nebraska State Prison, in making a report of my work for the past biennium. The attendance at our religious service is voluntary. I am glad to say that the boys of my faith have in the past two years been very attentive to their duties. The words of encouragement I have received from the boys in con - versation make me feel that good is being accomplished. The official chaplain, E. M. Johnson and the deceased chaplain Rev. P. C. Johnson, whose death I regretted very much, have always treated me with the utmost courtesy. I wish to thank Warden Fenton and his family for the hospitality extended to me. I also wish to thank the guards for their courtesy and I desire to thank the inmates for their attention and respectful manner during the services. Respectfully yours. Rev. Robert F. Moran. Denton, Nebraska, November JO, 191i.

The prison population at the beginning of my services was 381 and 424 have been admitted since, making a total of 805 inmates under medical observation. Of this number 451 have not been excused from duty by reason of either sickness or accident. 354 have been excused to cell by reason of accident or minor ailment. 151 have been placed in hospital by reason of more serious accident or illness. Seven men have died, which is a mortality of less than one per cent. The average daily number of those excused by reason of accident or confinement in hospital does not exceed three per cent. Of the whole number there are 284 that 1 class as re - formable, 97 doubtful and 43 nonreformable. Fifteen inmates have been examined by a legal board of insanity and have been transferred to the hospital for the insane by order of the Governor and Board of Commis - sioners. Of this number 6 were positively insane when committed. To me the work as prison physician has been very at - tractive and I have not realized a sitrn of a burden in the performance of my duties. I would feel selfish and ungrate - ful did I not express to you my aopreciation of your co-op - eration, also that of Deputy Warden Harmon and Mr. Kavanaugh, Steward Kirby and Chaplain Johnson in im - proving the mental and physical condition of the inmates and the sanitation of the institution. Very Respectfully, G. E. Williams. Prison Physician. Lincoln, Nebraska, November SO, 1914.
